metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (phenology camera observation data set of Sidaoqiao Superstation-2020）
metadata.description:
	The dataset contains the phenological camera observation data of the Sidaoqiao Superstation in the downstream reaches of Heihe integrated observatory network before May 31 and after September 2, 2020. Due to the power failure of phenological camera, the time is lost from May 31 to September 2, 2020. In addition, after the camera was moved and reinstalled, the object in the field of view before May 31 and after September 2 would change, which may cause the inconsistency of the data before and after. The site (101.137° E, 42.001° N) was located on a tamarix (Tamarix chinensis Lour.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 873 m. The instrument was developed and data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures data by look-downward with a resolution of 1280×720. For the calculation of the phenology, firstly, The phenological index needs to be calculated according to the region of interest. Such as, the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)). Then, controlling the quality of data, filling the invalid value and filtering smoothing are performed. Finally, the key phenological parameters are determined according to the growth curve fitting, such as the growth season start date, peak, growth season end, etc. This data set includes the relative greenness index (GCC) in 2020.
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'phenology camera observation data' in the context of environmental monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Phenology camera observation data refers to the visual data collected using cameras to monitor and study the timing of seasonal events in ecosystems, such as leaf-out, flowering, and senescence. This data is crucial for understanding ecological responses to environmental changes.

Definition.Question: What does 'relative greenness index (GCC)' mean in the context of vegetation monitoring?
Definition.Answer: The relative greenness index, or GCC (Green Chromatic Coordinate), is a measure used in vegetation monitoring to quantify the proportion of green color in images captured by cameras. It is calculated using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, and B represent the red, green, and blue pixel values in an image. This index helps assess plant health and growth stages.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the ecological balance in oasis-desert systems from the long-term observational data of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes?
Interpretation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial to recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting ecological stability and supporting sustainable development of oases, which in turn is important for achieving goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert areas.

Interpretation.Question: How do challenges like drying rivers and land desertification influence the data collection needs in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Interpretation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face environmental degradation challenges such as drying rivers, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges necessitate the collection of comprehensive datasets that include long-term observations of hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters to understand and mitigate these effects.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the methods used in data collection regarding the interaction of oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The methods used in data collection, which include long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations as well as hydrometeorological data, provide a suite of observational datasets that are crucial for understanding the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems. These methods help in recognizing the basic characteristics of these interactions necessary for maintaining ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes inconsistencies in observational data collected from phenology cameras, particularly in terms of target changes within the field of view?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inconsistencies in observational data from phenology cameras can be caused by events such as camera movement and reinstallation, which alter the field of view and thus the target objects being observed. This was noted in the metadata, where the camera was moved and reinstalled, causing changes in the observed targets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to data gaps in phenology camera observations in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data gaps in phenology camera observations can result from technical issues such as power supply failures, which were specifically mentioned as causing a time period of missing data in the observational dataset.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might oasis-desert systems in arid and semi-arid regions play a significant role in the global carbon cycle?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Oasis-desert systems in arid and semi-arid regions are considered significant within the global carbon cycle as they have been identified as carbon sinks, meaning they can sequester carbon from the atmosphere, thereby affecting the carbon balance of arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the integration of relative greenness index (GCC) calculations in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of relative greenness index (GCC) calculations in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems can lead to a better understanding of key phenological stages, such as the start and end of the growing season, which is crucial for maintaining ecological balance and supporting sustainable development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of employing long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges can result in a more quantitative understanding of oasis–desert interactions, which is significant for protecting ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development in the regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas and supporting their ecological security and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance is critical to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development, as oases are the core ecological landscapes in these regions and play a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in ensuring quality control and consistency in data collected from phenological cameras in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control for phenological camera data involves calculating phenological indices like the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC) from image pixel values, filling invalid values, smoothing the data through filtering, and fitting growth curves to determine key phenological parameters such as the start and end of the growing season.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collected and processed in oasis-desert ecosystems to maintain ecological balance?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Additional data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and meteorological parameters are obtained from automatic weather stations. The data undergo processing and quality control that includes data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing to support ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are implemented in the long-term observation of oasis-desert interactions to analyze energy and carbon exchange?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observation of oasis-desert interactions involves acquiring datasets from artificial and natural systems, measuring energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, and collecting auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data. Observations are conducted using a network of flux and meteorological stations, with data processed to understand the interactions and their impact on ecological stability.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term monitoring in oasis–desert ecosystems is enabled by observational datasets from artificial and natural systems, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These utilize an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data, along with hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations recorded every 10 minutes.

Enablement.Question: How have technological advancements in phenological cameras facilitated the collection of consistent data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Phenological cameras integrated with data acquisition and transmission capabilities have facilitated consistent data collection by capturing high-resolution images in a designated time frequency. These cameras use a vertical downward approach to gather data, which is processed to calculate phenological indices like the relative greenness index (GCC) for phenological analysis.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be overcome to maintain the accuracy and consistency of datasets in regions prone to ecological degradation?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include addressing ecological degradation issues such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors complicate data collection and necessitate robust quality control, data validation, and the overcoming of equipment failures, as seen in the interruption of data collection due to power supply issues with phenological cameras.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected consistency in data collected by phenological cameras at superstations be challenging to achieve?
Expectation.Answer: The expected consistency in data collected by phenological cameras can be difficult to achieve due to factors such as equipment failures, like the power supply issue that occurred, and changes in the camera's field of view after reinstallation, which can lead to discrepancies in recorded data.

Expectation.Question: What are some anticipated obstacles when aiming to maintain long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Anticipated obstacles include ecological environment degradation issues like the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification, as well as the logistical challenges of maintaining equipment and ensuring consistent data collection over extended periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in achieving a thorough quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Difficulties in achieving a comprehensive understanding may arise from the complexity of balancing oasis and desert systems, the variations in environmental conditions, and the need for long-term and diverse datasets that cover multiple parameters such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you believe the use of phenological cameras is in capturing accurate and consistent data for the analysis of seasonal changes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Phenological cameras offer a practical approach for monitoring seasonal changes, providing detailed visual data that can be analyzed for phenology indicators such as the relative greenness index (GCC). However, challenges such as equipment malfunctions and changes in camera positioning can affect data consistency and accuracy, as seen with the issues reported in the 2020 dataset due to power supply failures and camera repositioning.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets for oasis–desert systems, and how might these impact the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems is challenging due to ecological degradation issues such as drying rivers and land desertification. These environmental challenges can hinder data collection and lead to incomplete datasets, which may impact the comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges necessary for achieving carbon neutrality and ecological stability in these regions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what is the significance of integrating multiple data sources, such as hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters, in enhancing the robustness of datasets used in arid region studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple data sources, like hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters, significantly enhances the robustness of datasets by providing a more comprehensive understanding of the ecosystem dynamics in arid regions. This integration allows for a more accurate analysis of interactions between different environmental factors, supporting the creation of more effective management strategies for sustaining oasis–desert systems.

Assertion.Answer: The data collection method involves using phenological cameras installed at specific sites, which capture images at a resolution of 1280x720 pixels. These images are used to compute phenological indices, such as the relative greenness index (GCC), after performing quality control and filtering to ensure reliability. However, issues like power supply failures or camera relocations can affect data consistency.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced when maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert systems.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and land desertification. These factors, along with technical issues like equipment failures, can impact the maintenance of long-term datasets in the dynamic and harsh conditions of oasis-desert systems.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how auxiliary data like vegetation and soil parameters are integrated with flux observations in these datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Auxiliary data, including vegetation and soil parameters, are supplemented alongside energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These are collected through an integrated observational approach using eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations to provide comprehensive datasets for analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please conduct a search for potential methodologies to ensure consistency and accuracy in phenological camera observations, especially in cases of equipment failure or relocation.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ensuring consistency in phenological camera observations can involve implementing quality control procedures, such as filling in missing data, filtering, and smoothing the data. When equipment failure or relocation occurs, recalibrating the camera's field of view and using data processing techniques to align the new data with previous observations are crucial to maintaining accuracy.
